attributes.title: Does Conjoint Analysis Mitigate Social Desirability Bias?

q1.value: Does Conjoint Analysis Mitigate Social Desirability Bias?

q2.value: Yusaku Horiuchi | Zachary Daniel Markovich | Teppei Yamamoto

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: The purpose of the study is to investigate how social norms influence the responses given to questions asked in a variety of formats. Specifically, we test empirically whether conjoint surveys can mitigate biases in responses to socially sensitive question items in online surveys. Survey respondents often fail to provide truthful responses to questions that deal with socially sensitive issues. Such social desirability bias (SDB) is an important concern in survey research. Among the methods that have been proposed to mitigate SDB, conjoint analysis has become a popular approach when researchers seek to analyze respondents’ preferences about object that vary in multiple attributes, including ones that are socially sensitive. Yet, there has been little if any empirical investigation in the literature that attempts to quantify the degree to which conjoint analysis can reduce SDB. In this study we use a novel randomized controlled survey design to measure the reduction in SDB that can be attributed to conjoint analysis. We use two separate conjoint surveys to analyze respondents’ preferences about potentially socially sensitive issues: use of eco-friendly materials in hypothetical athletic shoes (the “shoes survey” hereafter) and race of hypothetical romantic partners on online dating service (the “dating survey” hereafter). In the shoes survey, we show respondents 10 pairs of hypothetical athletic shoes profiles varying in terms of 10 attributes and ask them to score each profile. In the dating survey, we show respondents 10 pairs of hypothetical profiles of a potential romantic partner that are varying in terms of 10 attributes, and ask them to rate and choose from the profiles. In both surveys, half of the respondents are presented with the pairs of profiles for which only one of the attributes is varying between the two profiles within each pair (thereby making the researcher’s intended goal of the study conspicuous to the respondents), while the other half are shown pairs of profiles with all attributes randomly varying within and across the pairs (thereby the intended goal of the study is not apparent). The purpose of the design is to investigate if respondents will on average show different preferences for socially sensitive attributes depending on the change in the survey design.

q16.value: We hypothesize that a study subject is more likely to make a socially desirable choice when only a socially-sensitive attribute varies between a pair of profiles, as compared to when all attributes vary between them. A specific procedure to test this hypothesis is explained in C3.

q17.value: We run two randomized conjoint experiment using Amazon.com Mechanical Turk (MTurk). Respondents will be residents of the US who are 18 years old or older for the shoes survey, and 20-60 years old and self-identified as white for the dating survey. The study will initially employ 200 respondents for each of the two surveys. After this “pilot” stage, we will then proceed to the “main study” stage where we will have the maximum of 2,000 respondents for either one (or both) of the two surveys. The purpose of proceeding in two stages is to test the validity of the responses in the initial stage so we can optimize the resulting data. The estimated completion time is 5-6 minutes for each survey. Participants will be paid $0.50 for completing the survey. The surveys will be programmed using Qualtrics software. Data will be downloaded from Qualtrics upon completion of the survey waves. In the shoes survey, respondents will be presented with 10 paired profiles of hypothetical athletic shoes that vary on a series of 10 characteristics -- Ave. Customer Review, Price, Weight, Eco-Friendly Materials (*), Brand, Gel Cushioning (**), Model year, Shipping, Color, Best Seller. Half of respondents are presented with pairs of profiles, in which either the “treated” attribute (*) or the “control” attribute (**) varies between the profiles. All other attributes are randomly selected from the predetermined sets of levels, but the levels are constant between the profiles. We call this type of conjoint experiment a “constrained conjoint” experiment. Other half of respondents will be presented with pairs of profiles, in which all attributes could vary. We call this type of conjoint experiment a “unconstrained conjoint” experiment. In each conjoint task, respondents will be asked the following question: “Imagine that you were shopping online for a new pair of athletic shoes and saw the following two descriptions for a pair of shoes. …. What do you think your percent chance of buying each would be?” A slider ranging from 0 (Never) to 100 (Always) is used for each profile (“Shoe 1” or “Shoe 2”). In the dating survey, respondents will be also presented with 10 paired profiles of hypothetical athletic shoes that vary on a series of 10 characteristics -- Political Views, Hobbies, Occupation (**), Want Kids, Body Type, Race/Ethnicity (*), Education, Age, Faith, Smoke. Similarly, half of respondents are presented with pairs of profiles, in which only either the “treated” attribute (*) or the “control” attribute (**) varies between the profiles. Other half of respondents will be presented with pairs of profiles, in which all attributes could vary. In each conjoint task, respondents will be asked the following question: “Imagine that you were seeking a new romantic partner on a dating app and saw the following two profiles. ... What do you think your percent chance of contacting each would be?” A slider ranging from 0 (Never) to 100 (Always) is used for each profile (“Profile 1” or “Profile 2”). We estimate the average marginal component effects (AMCEs) of levels for the treated attribute, as well as for the control attributes, in the constrained conjoint and unconstrained conjoint experiments. The difference-in-differences in these estimates is our quantity of interest. Specifically, we first take two differences -- (a) the difference between AMCEs of levels for the treated attribute and AMCEs of levels for the control attribute in the constrained experiment, and (b) the difference between AMCE of levels for the treated attribute and AMCE of levels for the control attribute in the unconstrained experiment). We then take the difference between (a) and (b). The baseline for the socially desirable level is “No Eco-Friendly Materials Used” for “Eco-Friendly Materials” in the shoes survey, and “White” for “Race/Ethnicity” in the dating survey. Compared to the baseline, respondents are more likely to choose “100% Eco-Friendly Materials Used” in the shoes survey, or non-white (i.e., “Black”, “Asian”, or “Hispanic”) in the dating survey. This effect is compared with the effects of levels for the control attribute and the effects in the unconstrained survey. We expect this difference-in-differences estimate to be positive.

attributes.title: Immigrant Attributes and the Moderating Role of Social Contact: A Conjoint Experiment

q1.value: Immigrant Attributes and the Moderating Role of Social Contact: A Conjoint Experiment

q2.value: Katherine Clayton | Jeremy Ferwerda | Yusaku Horiuchi

q5.value: We thank the Society for Political Methodology, as well as Dartmouth College’s Nelson A. Rockefeller Center for Public Policy, Neukom Institute, Undergraduate Advising and Research, and Department of Government, for providing financial support.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Public opinion about immigration is complex, and attitudes towards immigrants may vary based on the “type” of immigrants that come to mind when natives are asked about their preferences. Previous research has shown that immigrant attributes such as country of origin, religion, or occupational status have strong effects on natives’ views towards immigrants. However, in a landmark study, Hainmueller and Hopkins (2015) identified an important limitation in the literature: namely, few studies have tested the relative strength of multiple immigrant attributes, and instead have focused solely on the influence of attributes that receive the most attention in the literature on immigration. To mitigate these concerns, Hainmueller and Hopkins (2015) used fully randomized conjoint analysis to test how nine different immigrant attributes affected support for immigrants. Using this approach, Hainmueller and Hopkins found that respondents did indeed prioritize some attributes over others when selecting hypothetical immigrants for admission to the United States. Respondents prioritized immigrants in high-status jobs and immigrants who were educated. They actively discriminated against those who lacked plans to work, entered the country without authorization, were from Iraq, or had low English proficiency. They marginally preferred immigrants who were escaping political or religious persecution, and those who had previously visited the United States legally. They concluded that in the United States, immigration attitudes are motivated by concerns about immigrants’ adherence to national norms, and by their expected economic contribution to the country (sociotropic concerns). Aside from one study that used conjoint analysis to explore multidimensional views towards refugees in western Europe (Bansak, Hainmueller, and Hangartner 2016), no previous research has explored French natives’ preferences for different types of immigrants based on multiple attributes. However, important country-level differences in attitudes towards immigrants may exist (e.g., Citrin and Sides 2008). Drawing inspiration from Hainmueller and Hopkins, we therefore apply conjoint analysis to study attitudes towards immigrants among French natives. We also investigate whether preferences vary by respondents’ experiences of social contact with immigrants—namely, whether French natives who regularly experience positive, everyday contact with immigrants prioritize different immigrant attributes than do low-contact natives. Previous literature on the effects of social contact on prejudice tends to examine prejudice as the main outcome variable and contact as the key explanatory variable. Thus, our objectives are to explore the role of contact as a moderator, and to apply conjoint analysis to evaluate multidimensional attitudes towards immigration in the context of France.

q16.value: Our two hypotheses and one research question are as follows: Hypothesis 1: French natives will favor immigrants who are educated, who come from western democracies, who speak French, who hold higher-level professions, and who have plans to work. Hypothesis 2: French natives will disfavor immigrants who are uneducated, who come from non-western democracies, who do not speak French, who hold low-skilled professions, who lack plans to work, and who have previously entered France without legal authorization. Research Question 1: Does social contact with immigrants moderate the immigrant attributes that French natives prioritize?

q17.value: We run a fully randomized conjoint experiment written in French on a sample of 1500-2000 French natives to test how various immigrant attributes impact natives’ immigrant preferences. After answering some initial demographic questions on age, sex, and residency, respondents will be presented with 10 paired profiles of hypothetical immigrants that vary on a series of nine characteristics. The order of attributes is randomized for each respondent, but the order of attributes across the ten tasks in fixed for each respondent, and the levels for the attributes are randomly selected for each profile. The characteristics included are the following: country of origin, prior trips to the France, reason for immigrating, language skills, profession, job experience, employment plans, education level, and gender. Each attribute includes 2-11 levels. For example, the “employment plans” attribute can take on the levels, “Has a contract with a French employer,” “Does not have a contract with a French employer, but has done job interviews,” “Will look for work after arriving in France,” or “Has no plans to work at this time.” We note that there are a few cross-attribute constraints that prevent highly unrealistic profiles from being generated. Specifically, if a hypothetical immigrant has a high-skilled profession (e.g., doctor, researcher, financial analyst, professor, programmer), their education level must be higher than “2-year degree” (if profession = nurse, educational level must be higher than “high school degree”). Additionally, if a hypothetical immigrant’s country of origin is in the EU, their prior trips to France do not include the options “visited once before on a tourist visa,” “visited several times before on a tourist visa,” or “entered the country illegally without authorization,” because EU nationals can move freely across European borders, and their reason for immigrating does not include “escape religious/political persecution.” There is also one constraint on attribute ordering such that the “profession,” “job experience,” and “employment plans” attributes always appear together, in that order (although the location of this block of attributes among other attributes is randomized). Finally, we implement randomization weights so that the various “country of origin” attributes (even those that are subject to cross-attribute constraints) show up with roughly equal probability, which prevents respondents from being primed to think about certain countries over others. After viewing each profile, respondents are asked to choose which applicant they would prefer to see admitted to France. They will then answer a series of additional demographic questions on their education level and income, questions on their political preferences, a battery of three questions designed to gauge their level of social contact with immigrants, and a question about their views on immigration policy. The survey concludes with an opportunity to provide written feedback. For our analysis, we will calculate the average marginal component effect (AMCE), or the average effect of changing each immigrant attribute on natives’ preferences for one immigrant over another, relative to a baseline level. We will also estimate how key attributes, such as country of origin and profession, are conditional on other attributes, by estimating the average component interaction effects (ACIEs). Finally, we will compare the AMCEs among subgroups of respondents with high vs. low social contact with immigrants to discern heterogeneous effects. We have multiple measures of social contact. We will use each measure of contact elicited by the three social contact questions as a separate moderator, and/or as an index. We will also create high- vs. low-contact respondent groups by using data on the immigrant population in French municipalities, and will link this to data on respondents’ postal codes to determine whether they live in an area with a “very large,” “large,” “small,” or “very small” immigrant population, which correspond to four quartiles based on the foreign population in each area designated by a postal code in metropolitan France.

attributes.title: Media Framing, Attitudes Towards Immigration, the Moderating Role of Social Contact

q1.value: Media Framing, Attitudes Towards Immigration, the Moderating Role of Social Contact

q2.value: Katherine Clayton | Jeremy Ferwerda | Yusaku Horiuchi

q5.value: We thank the Society for Political Methodology, as well as Dartmouth College’s Nelson A. Rockefeller Center for Public Policy, Neukom Institute, Undergraduate Advising and Research, and Department of Government, for providing financial support.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Media frames exert powerful influences on people’s attitudes toward issues, individuals, and groups. Some research has suggested that the framing effects may be particularly large when it comes to coverage of immigration-related issues (Atwell Seate and Mastro 2016, Hopkins 2010), because public knowledge about immigration is low (Citrin and Sides 2008), because frames often emphasize threats to public safety or national security (Binder et al 2009, Bleiker et al. 2013, Fryberg et al. 2012), and because people hold competing considerations about immigration (Druckman, Peterson, and Slothuus 2013). In this case, the power of frames may be dependent on individuals’ experiences of contact with immigrant populations. In a randomized survey experiment, Ferwerda, Flynn, and Horiuchi (2017) showed that individuals living in refugee-dense areas in the United States were less susceptible to a frame that portrayed refugees as security threat. Similarly, Bohman (2015) showed that European natives with immigrant friends or colleagues were less likely to be negatively influenced by nationalist frames. Drawing some inspiration from these studies, we run a randomized survey experiment testing whether exposure to a threatening (counter-threatening) frame about immigrants decreases (increases) French natives’ support for immigration into their communities or into France as a whole. Examining support for community-level and country-level immigration allows us to explore whether French natives exhibit the attitudes of “not-in-my-backyard” syndrome (or NIMBYism) in the context of immigration, or the tendency to support immigration in general but oppose immigrants nearby. We also test whether the effect of a threatening or counter-threatening frame on support for immigration varies among respondents with high vs. low social contact with immigrants. Previous studies on the effects of social contact on prejudice tend to examine prejudice as the main outcome variable and contact as the key independent variable. Thus, our objectives are to explore the role of contact as a moderator, and to expand the literature on media frames, immigration, and NIMBYism to the context of France.

q16.value: Our four hypotheses and two research questions are as follows: Hypothesis 1: Exposure to threatening media frames that highlight a link between immigrants and terrorism will reduce French natives’ support for immigrants in their country and/or communities. Hypothesis 2: Exposure to counter-threatening frames that suggest that there is no link between immigrants and terrorism will have no effect on French natives’ support for immigrants in their country and/or communities. Hypothesis 3: The effect of exposure to information that frames immigrants as threatening on attitudes towards immigration will vary based on natives’ social contact with immigrants. Specifically, the threatening frame will create greater opposition to immigrants nationally and/or locally among natives with low contact with immigrants than among natives with high contact with immigrants. Hypothesis 4: French natives will be less supportive of immigration into their communities than immigration into France as a whole. Research Question 1: How will the effect of exposure to counter-threatening frames on support for immigration vary among natives with high and low contact with immigrants? Research Question 2: How will preferences for community-level immigration and country-level immigration vary among natives with high and low contact with immigrants?

q17.value: In a randomized online survey experiment written in French, we present a sample of 1500-2000 native French respondents with an article excerpt that frames immigrants in either a threatening or a counter-threatening way. There is also a control condition that does not read an article. The threatening article highlights a link between immigration and terrorism, while the counter-threatening article argues that immigration does not lead to terrorism. After answering some initial demographic questions on age, sex, and residency, respondents in the two treatment groups will read the article excerpt, and then all respondents will answer questions about their support for immigration nationally and locally. These two questions appear in a random order. Then, respondents will answer additional demographic questions, questions on their political preferences, a battery of three questions designed to gauge their level of social contact with immigrants, and a question about their views on immigration policy. The survey concludes with an opportunity to provide written feedback. We have multiple measures of social contact. We will use each measure of contact elicited by the three social contact questions as a separate moderator, and/or as an index. We will also create high- vs. low-contact respondent groups by using data on the immigrant population in French municipalities, and will link this to data on respondents’ postal codes to determine whether they live in an area with a “very large,” “large,” “small,” or “very small” immigrant population, which correspond to four quartiles based on the foreign population in each area designated by a postal code in metropolitan France. We will then estimate the treatment effects based on regression analysis, and compare the estimated effects among subgroups of respondents with low and high social contact with immigrants based on the multiple measures, to discern whether and how contact exerts a moderating influence. For the continuous moderator (i.e., the percentage of immigrants), we will also apply a semi-parametric approach to estimate the interaction effects, as suggested by Hainmueller, Mummolo, and Xu (2017).

registration_responses.q16: Our four hypotheses and two research questions are as follows: Hypothesis 1: Exposure to threatening media frames that highlight a link between immigrants and terrorism will reduce French natives’ support for immigrants in their country and/or communities. Hypothesis 2: Exposure to counter-threatening frames that suggest that there is no link between immigrants and terrorism will have no effect on French natives’ support for immigrants in their country and/or communities. Hypothesis 3: The effect of exposure to information that frames immigrants as threatening on attitudes towards immigration will vary based on natives’ social contact with immigrants. Specifically, the threatening frame will create greater opposition to immigrants nationally and/or locally among natives with low contact with immigrants than among natives with high contact with immigrants. Hypothesis 4: French natives will be less supportive of immigration into their communities than immigration into France as a whole. Research Question 1: How will the effect of exposure to counter-threatening frames on support for immigration vary among natives with high and low contact with immigrants? Research Question 2: How will preferences for community-level immigration and country-level immigration vary among natives with high and low contact with immigrants?
registration_responses.q17: In a randomized online survey experiment written in French, we present a sample of 1500-2000 native French respondents with an article excerpt that frames immigrants in either a threatening or a counter-threatening way. There is also a control condition that does not read an article. The threatening article highlights a link between immigration and terrorism, while the counter-threatening article argues that immigration does not lead to terrorism. After answering some initial demographic questions on age, sex, and residency, respondents in the two treatment groups will read the article excerpt, and then all respondents will answer questions about their support for immigration nationally and locally. These two questions appear in a random order. Then, respondents will answer additional demographic questions, questions on their political preferences, a battery of three questions designed to gauge their level of social contact with immigrants, and a question about their views on immigration policy. The survey concludes with an opportunity to provide written feedback. We have multiple measures of social contact. We will use each measure of contact elicited by the three social contact questions as a separate moderator, and/or as an index. We will also create high- vs. low-contact respondent groups by using data on the immigrant population in French municipalities, and will link this to data on respondents’ postal codes to determine whether they live in an area with a “very large,” “large,” “small,” or “very small” immigrant population, which correspond to four quartiles based on the foreign population in each area designated by a postal code in metropolitan France. We will then estimate the treatment effects based on regression analysis, and compare the estimated effects among subgroups of respondents with low and high social contact with immigrants based on the multiple measures, to discern whether and how contact exerts a moderating influence. For the continuous moderator (i.e., the percentage of immigrants), we will also apply a semi-parametric approach to estimate the interaction effects, as suggested by Hainmueller, Mummolo, and Xu (2017).

attributes.title: Misperceptions about Immigrants, Acceptance of Corrections, and the Moderating Role of Social Contact

q1.value: Misperceptions about Immigrants, Acceptance of Corrections, and the Moderating Role of Social Contact

q2.value: Katherine Clayton | Jeremy Ferwerda | Yusaku Horiuchi

q5.value: We thank the Society for Political Methodology, as well as Dartmouth College’s Nelson A. Rockefeller Center for Public Policy, Neukom Institute, Undergraduate Advising and Research, and Department of Government, for providing financial support.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Using randomized survey experiments, previous studies on misinformation and corrections have shown that individuals exposed to corrective information will welcome it when it is consistent with their preexisting beliefs or worldview, and will reject information that contradicts what they already believe (Nyhan and Reifler 2010). In some cases, corrections may even backfire, and strengthen misperceptions among ideological subgroups most committed to their preexisting false beliefs (Nyhan and Reifler 2010). Even if individuals accept corrections to false information, they do not necessarily update their attitudes and beliefs; indeed, exposure to negative political information may create “belief echoes” and continues to shape individuals’ attitudes even after the information has been effectively discredited (Thorson 2016). Although this growing literature examining the effects of political misinformation and corrections has focused on the United States, misinformation is a global issue. In France in particular, fake news and false information spread by political elites captured media headlines throughout the 2017 French presidential election. In this context, we examine how exposure to false information about immigrants, and/or corrections to this information, affects French natives’ perceived accuracy of the false information and their attitudes towards immigration in general. We also examine heterogeneous treatment effects by respondents’ level of social contact with immigrants, or how often they have positive, everyday interactions with individuals born outside of France. Previous studies on the effects of social contact on prejudice tend to examine prejudice as the main outcome variable and contact as the key explanatory variable. Thus, our objectives are to explore the role of contact as a moderator, and to expand the political misinformation literature to the context of France.

q16.value: Our four hypotheses and one research question are as follows: Hypothesis 1: Exposure to misinformation and a correction will reduce perceived accuracy of a false statement about immigrants, relative to a misinformation-only condition. Hypothesis 2: The effect of exposure to false information about immigrants on perceived accuracy of a false statement will vary based on natives’ level of social contact with immigrants. Namely, natives who have higher social contact with immigrants will show lower belief in a false statement about immigrants than natives who have lower social contact with immigrants. Hypothesis 3: The efficacy of corrections to false information will vary based on natives’ level of social contact with immigrants. Specifically, corrections will be more effective at reducing misperceptions among natives with higher social contact with immigrants than among natives with lower contact with immigrants. Hypothesis 4: Exposure to misinformation and/or corrections will create belief echoes. Respondents exposed to misinformation only will exhibit the most negative attitudes towards immigration, followed by respondents exposed to misinformation with a correction. Respondents exposed to no information will exhibit the least negative attitudes towards immigration. Research Question 1: Will the formation of belief echoes vary among natives with high vs. low social contact with immigrants?

q17.value: In a randomized online survey experiment written in French, we present a sample of 1500-2000 native French respondents with an article excerpt containing a false statement about immigrants, an excerpt containing the false statement and a correction, or no information. The false statement was made by a leader in the far-right French nationalist party, the Front National, and asserts that immigrants have better access to state-sponsored health care than do French natives. The correction to this statement affirms that this is not the case; state-sponsored health care for French citizens includes more coverage than the health program available to foreigners. After answering some initial demographic questions on age, sex, and residency, respondents in the two treatment groups will read the article excerpt. Then, all respondents will answer a question measuring their perceived accuracy of the false statement made in the article, additional demographic questions, questions on their political preferences, a battery of three questions designed to gauge their level of social contact with immigrants, and a question about their views on immigration policy. The survey concludes with an opportunity to provide written feedback. We have multiple measures of social contact. We will use each measure of contact elicited by the three social contact questions as a separate moderator, and/or as an index. We will also create high- vs. low-contact respondent groups by using data on the immigrant population in French municipalities, and will link this to data on respondents’ postal codes to determine whether they live in an area with a “very large,” “large,” “small,” or “very small” immigrant population, which correspond to four quartiles based on the foreign population in each area designated by a postal code in metropolitan France. We will then estimate the treatment effects based on regression analysis, and compare the estimated effects among subgroups of respondents with low and high social contact with immigrants based on the multiple measures, to discern whether and how contact exerts a moderating influence. For the continuous moderator (i.e., the percentage of immigrants), we will also apply a semi-parametric approach to estimate the interaction effects, as suggested by Hainmueller, Mummolo, and Xu (2017).

attributes.title: Media source and susceptibility to false information

q1.value: Media source and susceptibility to false information

q2.value: Yusaku Horiuchi | Katherine Clayton | Jase Davis | Kristen Hinckley

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: In the past year, concerns about political misinformation have skyrocketed. President Trump’s claims about various media outlets including CNN, the New York Times, and MSNBC spreading “fake news” have only added to a growing sentiment among the American population that the mainstream news media is untrustworthy. However, some evidence suggests that while Americans have low trust in the media in general, they trust media sources that they use—and choice of media source is highly partisan in nature. This notion is consistent with a wide body of research pointing to a “hostile media effect,” by which partisans rate identical news coverage as being biased against their side. It also relates to research on the “echo chamber” or “selective exposure” phenomenon in the media; individuals gravitate towards news sources providing information that is consistent with their beliefs. The question remains, however, as to how far individuals’ trust in their preferred media source(s) goes. When presented with information that is false, will individuals perceive it to be accurate if it comes from a source that they trust? Will they want to read more about the topic from the source? Broadly, what matters more when it comes to how people ingest news: source or content? In a randomized survey experiment administered to a large sample of adults in the United States, we address these questions empirically. We seek to determine the effect of media source on perceived accuracy of false information contained in a news article excerpt, and interest in reading the rest of the article. By varying the media source and information content of the excerpts, and by collecting information on individuals’ ideological and partisan preferences, we can estimate whether and how source and/or content differentially impact belief in false information and interest in reading more by ideology/partisanship. We capitalize on a highly salient issue (health care reform), which has dominated media attention for the past several months. Our analysis will help us to better understand how Americans take in news and view the media in an era of major change and extreme political polarization.

q16.value: Outcome and Treatment Variables: Outcome 1 (Y1): “How interested are you in reading the rest of this article?” = 4 if Very interested, = 3 if Somewhat interested, = 2 if Not very interested, = 1 if Not at all interested Outcome 2 (Y2): “How accurate is the following statement? [Paragraph break] In the most recent versions of the new health care bills proposed by the House and Senate, young adults would lose health insurance coverage through their parents' insurance plan when they turn 18.” = 4 if Very Accurate, = 3 if Somewhat accurate, = 2 if Not very accurate, = 1 if Not at all accurate Treatment 1 (CNN): = 1 if the CNN header is shown, = 0 otherwise Treatment 2 (Fox News): = 1 if the Fox News header is shown, = 0 otherwise Treatment 3 (False): = 1 if false information is shown, = 0 otherwise Baseline category: Neither header is shown; true information is shown Models: Y1 = b0 + b1 * False + b2 * CNN + b3 * Fox News + b4 * False * CNN + b5 * False * Fox News + error Y2 = c0 + c1 * False + c2 * CNN + c3 * Fox News + c4 * False * CNN + c5 * False * Fox News + error Hypotheses: H1: Republicans/conservatives [Democrats/liberals] will be more interested in continuing to read the article from Fox News [CNN] than CNN [Fox News]. • [b2 (if Democrats/liberals) > b2 (if Republicans/conservatives)] When the true statement (baseline) is presented with the CNN header, Democrats/liberals will be more interested in reading the rest of the article, as compared to Republicans/conservatives. • [b3 (if Democrats/liberals) < b3 (if Republicans/conservatives)] When the true statement (baseline) is presented with the Fox News header, Democrats/liberals will be less interested in reading the rest of the article, as compared to Republicans/conservatives. H2: Republicans/conservatives [Democrats/liberals] will be more likely to believe that the false information is accurate when the information comes from Fox News [CNN] than when it comes from CNN [Fox News]. • [c4 (if Democrats/liberals) < c4 (if Republicans/conservatives) < 0] When the false statement is presented with the CNN header, Republicans/conservatives, as compared to Democrats/liberals, will be more likely to think that the statement is not accurate, even compared to the (false) statement without the headline. • [c5 (if Republicans/conservatives) < c5 (if Democrats/liberals) < 0] When the false statement is presented with the Fox News header, Democrats/liberals, as compared to Republicans/conservatives, will be more likely to think that the statement is not accurate, even compared to the (false) statement without the headline. Other Research Questions: [b1] When study participants are exposed to the false statement (without the CNN/Fox News header), are they more or less likely to read the rest of the article, compared to the true statement (without the CNN/Fox News header)? Does this effect differ by participants’ partisanship/ideology? [b4, b5] When the false statement is presented with the CNN header or the Fox News header, are study participants more or less interested in reading the rest of the article? Does this effect differ by study participants’ partisanship/ideology? [c1] When study participants are exposed to the false statement (without the CNN/Fox News header), are they more or less likely to think that the statement is accurate, compared to the true statement (without the CNN/Fox News header)? Does this effect differ by study participants’ partisanship/ideology? [c2, c3] When the true statement is presented with the CNN header or the Fox News header, are study participants more or less likely to think that the statement is accurate, as compared to the (true) statement without the headline? Does this effect differ by study participants’ partisanship/ideology?

q17.value: We will conduct a randomized survey experiment on a large sample (N = 2000-4000) of American adults using Amazon.com Mechanical Turk (MTurk). Participants will be randomly assigned to one of six groups in a 2x3 between-subjects research design. All survey respondents will first answer questions on demographics, political interest, trust in the media, partisanship/ideology, and political knowledge. Then, the randomly assigned groups will each read one of six versions of an article excerpt on health care bills. The content of the article excerpt will be either true or false information, and the source will be either CNN, Fox News, or will not be included (no source). The article title and author are constant across all treatment groups. After reading the article, all respondents will be asked the same two questions: (1) How interested are you in reading the rest of this article? (with the response options “very interested, somewhat interested, not very interested, not at all interested”), and (2) How accurate is the following statement? In the most recent versions of the new health care bills proposed by the House and Senate, young adults would lose health insurance coverage through their parents’ insurance plan when they turn 18 (with the response options “very accurate, somewhat accurate, not very accurate, not at all accurate”). Finally, respondents will see a debriefing message about the nature of the study that clarifies that the information was fabricated for the purpose of research. After collecting this data, we will estimate the effect of media source and information content on perceived accuracy of information and on interest in reading the rest of the article excerpt by ideology/partisanship according to the models specified in C2.

attributes.title: Influences of Regime Type on Public Opinion

q1.value: Influences of Regime Type on Public Opinion

q5.value: The Office of Undergraduate Advising and Research (UGAR) at Dartmouth College for funding

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The aim of this experiment is to identify factors that influence American public opinion of foreign countries, with an emphasis on regime type of the country in question. Although the democratic peace has been studied extensively, scholars disagree on both the existence of a causal relationship between regime type and state propensity for war and through which mechanisms this causal effect may operate. This study attempts to tease out the causal mechanisms of the effect of democracy on public opinion and public preferences for foreign policy choices. To do so, this study undertakes conjoint analysis to test the influence of democratic institutions and characteristics of foreign states on participants’ perceptions of states and policy preferences. Previous experiments exploring the influence of democracy on public opinion have identified a pacifying effect of “democracy” on participants’ perceptions of other states and preferences for policies; using two conjoint designs will allow us to identify whether “democracy” affects public opinion by influencing participant perceptions of state institutions or state characteristics such as majority race, majority religion, and location. Additionally, five dependent variables aim to identify which proposed mechanisms of the democratic peace are most plausible with regards to public opinion and allow us to test the possibility that while cultural characteristics and democratic institutions both contribute to the democratic peace, they may do so through different mechanisms.

attributes.title: Explaining Public Opinion towards Refugee Resettlement

q1.value: Explaining Public Opinion towards Refugee Resettlement

q2.value: Jeremy Ferwerda | D.J. Flynn | Yusaku Horiuchi

q5.value: We thank Brendan Nyhan for helpful input.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Refugee resettlement is an increasingly salient issue in American politics. This project examines the determinants of public preferences for refugee resettlement. We focus on two of the most widely studied determinants of public opinion towards immigrants: media framing and not-in-my-back-yard thinking (NIMBYism). We test the influence of media framing and NIMBYism on support for refugee resettlement using an online survey experiment. The design of our experiment is 3 (pro-refugee frame/anti-refugee frame/no frame) x 2 (national resettlement/local resettlement). We will use the experimental data to examine three hypotheses. First, we will test NIMBYism by examining whether participants are more supportive of national resettlement than local resettlement. Second, we will examine whether pro- and anti-refugee frames influence support for both forms of refugee resettlement. Third, we will test competing theoretical predictions about the extent of framing effects on support for national versus local resettlement. In addition to these hypotheses, we will also explore two research questions about heterogeneity in NIMBYism based on education and existing refugee population in participants’ local communities.

q17.value: Respondents and data collection: U.S. adults (18+) recruited from Amazon.com’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk) (Berinsky, Huber, and Lenz 2012). 2,994 participants who completed a pre-survey will be invited to participate in this study (see below). Dates of administration: February 7-9, 2017 Eligibility and exclusion criteria for participants: Participants will be recruited from an existing panel of 2,994 MTurk “workers” who completed a pre-survey on February 2, 2017. This pre-survey measured demographic, geographic, political, and psychological variables and did not include any questions related to refugees. Full survey instrument is available from the authors. Primary and secondary outcome measures: [We will randomize the order in which participants answer the national and local resettlement support dependent measures. Specifically, participants will answer (1) followed by (2) OR (3) followed by (4) before proceeding to the rest of the survey.] Do you support or oppose refugee resettlement in your local community? Suppose that people who feel that absolutely no refugees should be placed in your local community are at one end of a scale, at point 0; others who feel that as many refugees as possible should be placed in your local community are at the other end, at point 10. Where would you place YOURSELF on this scale? -0-10 slider with labels at 0 (“Absolutely no refugees”) and 10 (“As many refugees as possible”) What about the United States? Do you support or oppose refugee resettlement in the United States? Suppose that people who feel that absolutely no refugees should be placed in the United States are at one end of a scale, at point 0; others who feel that as many refugees as possible should be placed in the United States are at the other end, at point 10. Where would you place YOURSELF on this scale? -0-10 slider with labels at 0 (“Absolutely no refugees”) and 10 (“As many refugees as possible”) Do you support or oppose refugee resettlement in the United States? Suppose that people who feel that absolutely no refugees should be placed in the United States are at one end of a scale, at point 0; others who feel that as many refugees as possible should be placed in the United States are at the other end, at point 10. Where would you place YOURSELF on this scale? -0-10 slider with labels at 0 (“Absolutely no refugees”) and 10 (“As many refugees as possible”) What about your local community? Do you support or oppose refugee resettlement in your local community? Suppose that people who feel that absolutely no refugees should be placed in your local community are at one end of a scale, at point 0; others who feel that as many refugees as possible should be placed in your local community are at the other end, at point 10. Where would you place YOURSELF on this scale? -0-10 slider with labels at 0 (“Absolutely no refugees”) and 10 (“As many refugees as possible”) How much of a threat do refugees pose to the United States? -Major threat [3] -Minor threat [2] -Not a threat [1] Do you think that refugees will increase, decrease, or have no effect on the likelihood of terrorism in the United States? -Increase the likelihood of terrorism [3] -Decrease the likelihood of terrorism [1] -Have no effect on the likelihood of terrorism [2] Overall, do you think having an increasing number of people of many different races, ethnic groups, and nationalities in our country makes this country a better place to live, a worse place to live, or doesn't make much difference either way? -A better place to live [1] -A worse place to live [3] -Doesn’t make much difference either way [2] Do you agree or disagree with the Executive Order that President Trump signed blocking refugees and banning people from seven Muslim majority countries from entering the U.S.? -Strongly agree -Somewhat agree -Neither agree nor disagree -Somewhat disagree -Strongly disagree Statistical analyses: All models will be estimated using OLS regression with robust standard errors and verified for robustness using appropriate GLM estimators. All comparisons are between-subjects, using the first refugee resettlement outcome measure that each participant answered (as explained above, all participants answered both the national and local resettlement measure, but order was randomized). We may also report the same analyses using within-subject comparisons in an appendix. H1 (NIMBYism): Participants will be more supportive of national refugee resettlement than local refugee resettlement. We will calculate the difference-in-means between support for national refugee resettlement and local refugee resettlement. (Analysis limited to control group participants since this prediction does not involve media coverage.) H2a (Anti-refugee framing effects): Media frames that depict refugees as a threat to national security will decrease support for refugee resettlement. (Same prediction for both national and local resettlement.) We will calculate the difference-in-means between support for local (national) resettlement in the anti-refugee frame condition and support for local (national) resettlement in the control condition. (Participants in the pro-refugee frame condition excluded.) H2b (Pro-refugee framing effects): Media frames that depict refugees as non-threatening to national security will increase support for refugee resettlement. (Same prediction for both national and local resettlement.) We will examine whether pro-refugee frames increase support for both national and local refugee resettlement. To do so, we will calculate the difference-in-means between support for local (national) resettlement in the pro-refugee frame condition and support for local (national) resettlement in the control condition. (Participants in the anti-refugee frame condition excluded.) H3a (Magnitude of framing effects): Framing effects on support for national refugee resettlement will be larger than framing effects on support for local refugee resettlement. H3b (Magnitude of framing effects): Framing effects on support for local refugee resettlement will be larger than framing effects on support for national refugee resettlement. To examine whether framing effects are larger on support for either local or national refugee resettlement, we will pool responses to both the local and national resettlement outcome measures and use them in a single model. We will then estimate a regression model predicting support for resettlement based on the following variables: local (1=local resettlement, 0=national), negative frame (1=in condition, 0 otherwise), positive frame (1=in condition, 0 otherwise), and interactions between local x negative frame and local x positive frame. (Control participants are the omitted reference group.) Specifically, the model will take the following form: Support for refugee resettlement = b0 + b1*Local + b2*Positive Frame + b3*Negative Frame + b4*Local x Positive Frame + b5*Local x Negative Frame + e RQ1: Is NIMBYism more or less prevalent among highly educated participants? Extant literature suggests that education levels are a significant and positive predictor of support for immigration. Therefore, we will investigate whether negative attitudes towards refugee resettlement are moderated by education. We will evaluate this interaction by using self-provided information on education levels provided in a previous wave. RQ2: Is NIMBYism more or less prevalent among participants with a large existing refugee population in their local community? Empirical work has suggested that the density of immigrant settlement plays a role in shaping attitudes towards immigration, but only when debates are nationally salient (Hopkins 2010, 2011). We thus expect the effects of national frames to interact with the degree to which respondents are located within a community that has accepted refugees in the past. Notes: -We will compute and report appropriate auxiliary quantities from our models, including treatment effects by subgroup and differences in marginal effects between subgroups. -We will compute all marginal effects appropriate to test the hypotheses of interest from any interaction models described above. In some cases, we may present treatment effects estimated on different subsets of the data for expositional clarity. If so, we will verify that we can reject the null of no difference in treatment effects in a more complex interactive model reported in an appendix when possible. -”Don’t know” responses will be considered as missing data. -We will also compute and report summary statistics for our samples. We will also collect and may report response timing data as a proxy for respondent attention. -The order of hypotheses and analyses in the final manuscript may be altered for expositional clarity. - As robustness tests, we will also estimate post-stratification weights obtained via entropy balancing (Hainmueller 2012) and apply the weights in our tests.

registration_responses.q2: Jeremy Ferwerda | D.J. Flynn | Yusaku Horiuchi

registration_responses.q15: Refugee resettlement is an increasingly salient issue in American politics. This project examines the determinants of public preferences for refugee resettlement. We focus on two of the most widely studied determinants of public opinion towards immigrants: media framing and not-in-my-back-yard thinking (NIMBYism). We test the influence of media framing and NIMBYism on support for refugee resettlement using an online survey experiment. The design of our experiment is 3 (pro-refugee frame/anti-refugee frame/no frame) x 2 (national resettlement/local resettlement). We will use the experimental data to examine three hypotheses. First, we will test NIMBYism by examining whether participants are more supportive of national resettlement than local resettlement. Second, we will examine whether pro- and anti-refugee frames influence support for both forms of refugee resettlement. Third, we will test competing theoretical predictions about the extent of framing effects on support for national versus local resettlement. In addition to these hypotheses, we will also explore two research questions about heterogeneity in NIMBYism based on education and existing refugee population in participants’ local communities.

H3b (Magnitude of framing effects): Framing effects on support for local refugee resettlement will be larger than framing effects on support for national refugee resettlement. attributes.title: Diversity in Faculty Recruitment: Consensus or Disagreement among Students?

q1.value: Diversity in Faculty Recruitment: Consensus or Disagreement among Students?

q2.value: Yusaku Horiuchi | John Michael Carey | Madeline M. Brown | Lauren K. Martin

q5.value: We are grateful to Dartmouth College's Office of Institutional Research for providing the contact information for our sample of student survey respondents.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This study investigates Dartmouth College students' preferences for diversity on race/ethnicity, sex/gender, and other important attributes, in faculty recruitment. Instead of directly asking diversity-related questions, which could produce social desirability bias, we employ a novel measurement technique based on conjoint analysis (Hainmueller, Hopkins, and Yamamoto 2014). To the best of our knowledge, the proposed study will be the first to empirically analyze university students' preference for faculty diversity, and thus makes contributions not only to the academic literatures but also to actual policy debates on campus diversity in the United States.

q16.value: [H1a] Students who do not identify as white on race/ethnicity will have stronger preferences for recruitment of non-white prospective faculty members than will students who self-identify as white. [H1b] Positive affect on race/ethnicity should be strongest for candidates that match students' self-identification on race/ethnicity. [H2] Students who do not identify as male on gender will have stronger preferences for recruitment of non-male prospective faculty than will students who self-identify as male. [H3a] Students who do not identify as white on race/ethnicity will have stronger preferences for recruitment of non-male prospective faculty members than will students who self-identify as white. [H3b] Students who do not identify as male on gender will have stronger preferences for recruitment of non-white prospective faculty than will students who self-identify as male.

q17.value: We juxtapose sets of composite faculty members as hypothetical short-listed candidates for a faculty position at Dartmouth College and ask students to choose the most preferred candidate. Our study identifies the relative importance for students of various candidate attributes, such as race/ethnicity and sex/gender. By interacting the attributes of hypothetical candidates with the attributes of students themselves, this approach also allows us to investigate whether there is any hidden consensus or disagreement on faculty diversity among students, such as between majority (i.e., white) students and minority students.

q19.value: 2,257 (# of students receiving an invitation to participate in the survey)
